content:
@CiscoJunkie at the risk of just re-hashing the blog post. I used:
- https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8805
- IP ranges for AWS/GCP that they publish in a JSON format
- BGP Communities and next hops. There are some conventions for BGP communities. And if we know the location of the direct next hop, there's a chance that it's in the same city.
- Historical WHOIS dumps. Now we're getting down to low-quality data, but I look for the country and city in WHOIS entries. It also knows about a few conventions that some providers use, like China Telecom.

There's quite a few rabbit holes to jump down with this... but it was fun using public datasets for this. I know GeoIP is absolutely something people charge for, so I don't expect to get it anywhere close to perfectly correct.

card.title: RFC 8805: A Format for Self-Published IP Geolocation Feeds
card.description: This document records a format whereby a network operator can publish a mapping of IP address prefixes to simplified geolocation information, colloquially termed a "geolocation feed". Interested parties can poll and parse these feeds to update or merge with other geolocation data sources and procedures. This format intentionally only allows specifying coarse-level location. Some technical organizations operating networks that move from one conference location to the next have already experimentally published small geolocation feeds. This document describes a currently deployed format. At least one consumer (Google) has incorporated these feeds into a geolocation data pipeline, and a significant number of ISPs are using it to inform them where their prefixes should be geolocated.
